title: craigdonny
author: craigdonny
content: Tried to use low power mode but it stays at around 55th with abnormal highlighted. Any work arounds? Only thing i have found is someone on reddit who bought a epic umc control board.

comments.author: BitMaxz
comments.body: Check the ASIC status? There might be some missing ASIC chips that leads to abnormal status.If you want a better troubleshooting I suggest share your kernel logs here and maybe we can find some issue under that logs.Don't forget to put all logs with insert code tag.

comments.author: altair_tech
comments.body: Noticed the same issue on my S19jPro+ 120T with AMLOGIC CBRuns fine on full power but abnormal hashrate of 82-88T in Low power mode.Switched to Xilinx CB on the same miner and everything works great. 🎉Runs well on ePIC UMC as well. This has to be either a problem with AMLOGIC hardware or Bitmain's AMLOGIC firmware. Unfortunately, AMLOGIC is the predominant control board on these miners these days, so this affects a lot of people. Hopefully bitmain can fix this with a firmware update 🤞PS: 'The Menace' and 'The GOAT' are living up to their nicknames!

comments.author: china_dawn
comments.body: Quote from: craigdonny on July 03, 2023, 03:32:19 PMTried to use low power mode but it stays at around 55th with abnormal highlighted. Any work arounds? Only thing i have found is someone on reddit who bought a epic umc control board. Hello, my friend, I think your problem may be that the control board has lowered the voltage in low power mode, and a chip on this chain cannot work at low voltage due to manufacturing problems. Next, so the problem you mentioned will appearLow power consumption is nothing more than two conditions, one is to reduce the frequency, and the other is to reduce the power supply voltage of the PSU. The official firmware may not have much experience in this area, while the third-party firmware will have richer options. For example, a certain chip cannot If it works at low voltage, then we shield this chip so that it does not work, or increase the voltage of the PSU without increasing the frequency, at least the chain can work without causing a loss of computing powerFor example, the hulkos I use has such a function

comments.author: mikeywith
comments.body: What altair_tech as well as china_dawn mentioned ( although the latter seems like he is trying to promote his firmware) is pretty accurate, however, I need to add a little bit more info just to clear things for those who don't know.The underclocking of a miner requires two things1- Firmware / CB capable of doing it correctly.2- Hashboards that can withstand the lower voltage related to the underclock process. Most of the time it will be an issue with the firmware or control board but in many other cases it could be one or more chips that simply can't run at the given lower voltage, so no matter what firmware you use, it just won't work unless you crank up the voltage which could make the whole underclocking operation useless.It's even worse on these new miners because you can't set different voltages for each hashrate due to their physical design, on the older models like an S9, if there is just one hashboard that doesn't like the lower voltage, you could change it and keep the other two hashboard running at a lower voltage, sadly, not the case anymore.

Most of the time it will be an issue with the firmware or control board but in many other cases it could be one or more chips that simply can't run at the given lower voltage, so no matter what firmware you use, it just won't work unless you crank up the voltage which could make the whole underclocking operation useless.It's even worse on these new miners because you can't set different voltages for each hashrate due to their physical design, on the older models like an S9, if there is just one hashboard that doesn't like the lower voltage, you could change it and keep the other two hashboard running at a lower voltage, sadly, not the case anymore.or he could load braiins+ which tunes each and every chip and it should work.but braiins+ has a minimum watt setting of around 2475.Here is a 110th s19 pro set to 2472 watts.this setting saves 700-800 watts at a cost of 13thI used to do 110th at 3200 vs 97 at 2472I get a 72 board tempwhich allows fans to be slow around 3000-4000 rpm.As you can see it approaches s19xp  21 watt number

comments.author: china_dawn
comments.created_time: August 08, 2023, 04:37:19 PMLast edit: August 08, 2023, 04:56:11 PM by china_dawn
comments.body: Quote from: mikeywith on August 07, 2023, 11:39:11 PMWhat altair_tech as well as china_dawn mentioned ( although the latter seems like he is trying to promote his firmware) is pretty accurate, however, I need to add a little bit more info just to clear things for those who don't know.The underclocking of a miner requires two things1- Firmware / CB capable of doing it correctly.2- Hashboards that can withstand the lower voltage related to the underclock process. Most of the time it will be an issue with the firmware or control board but in many other cases it could be one or more chips that simply can't run at the given lower voltage, so no matter what firmware you use, it just won't work unless you crank up the voltage which could make the whole underclocking operation useless.It's even worse on these new miners because you can't set different voltages for each hashrate due to their physical design, on the older models like an S9, if there is just one hashboard that doesn't like the lower voltage, you could change it and keep the other two hashboard running at a lower voltage, sadly, not the case anymore.I mentioned the firmware I use, like you guys mentioned braiins+, I didn't send any firmware to any of you (This firmware is private and currently only available for internal testing and is not open to the public), I just stated my opinion on the issue, Don't think that whoever discusses with you is trying to sell you productsIn addition, the problem we discussed is because the new machine of the S19 series in the later period cancels the pic control chip and the switch MOS tube, so there is no way to control the voltage and power consumption of the power board independently by switching the switching frequency of the MOS, and there is no way to independently control the power consumption of the power board. Turn off or turn on a hashboardThis problem is nothing more than finding a hashboard with a better physique, which can work at a lower voltage threshold, or replace those chips with poor physique. The official firmware has many restrictions on the use conditions, while the third-party firmware will open These restrictions may also shield certain non-working chips (there is no technical obstacle), or the firmware adaptively increases the voltage threshold a little bit, you can find a few more firmware to try
